Enable run powershell as admin (in windows terminal): // https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/issues/632 { "guid": "{42f54c7a-0364-4ce2-bbb6-81efb79ec97f}", "hidden": false, "name": "Powershell (Admin)", "commandline": "%SystemRoot%\\System32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe -command Start-Process -Verb RunAs \"shell:appsFolder\\Microsoft.WindowsTerminal_8wekyb3d8bbwe!App\"", "icon": "ms-appx:///Images/Square44x44Logo.targetsize-32.png" } Remove that pesky right click context menu: $subPath = "HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Classes\packagedcom\package\" $skypePackageId = dir $subPath | ? { $_.Name -like '*skypeapp*' } | select-object -Property name | % { $_.Name } | split-path -Leaf $withoutClassId = "$subpath" + "$skypePackageId\class\" $classId = dir $withoutClassId | ? { $_.Property -like '*DllPath*' } | % { $_.Name } | split-path -leaf $pathWithClassId = "$subpath" + "$skypePackageId\class\$classId" if((Test-Path $pathWithClassId) -and ($classId -ne $null)) { Write-Host "Found $pathWithClassId" pushd $withoutClassId remove-item $classId -confirm popd }

entry.title: Docker plus Jekyll equals win
entry.content:
I‚Äôve started to spend more time looking at docker. A useful excerise has been to use the docker jekyll image to setup a working development environment.

Previously, it took me 2 days of configuring my windows 10 desktop with:

  • Correct version of Ruby installed
  • Ruby gems installed & configured correctly
  • Make installed (in the event you need to modify & rebuild some part of the toolchain)
  • Appropriate version of libcurl installed & setup

At any point in the setup process you will encounter an error, attempt to use google to get more context, scroll through various github issues & stackoverflow posts, and then try various combinations of command line arguments until each error is resolved.

Fast forward 6 months, a new OS update is applied which uknowingly touches one of those components and the whole stack of cards comes crashing down. In the software development world we are all too familiar with yak shaving.

Fortunately this problem has been solved. By using automation and the docker toolchain, the process now becomes a 2 hour task:

  • Install docker
  • Learn docker
  • Run 2 docker commands
  • Start developing

You could argue learning docker is yet more yak shaving, but the benefit to this learning, is that docker becomes another tool in the toolbox which can hugely shorten the software development and delivery lifecycle.

entry.title: Down the rabbit hole
entry.content:
‚ÄúJust setup jekyll on your local windows 10 machine‚Äù they said, how hard can it be?

You‚Äôve installed ruby, then jekyll. Created a site, found a theme, installed some gems, bundled something and now you have some html served up on port 4000. But wait a minute, now your console is full of warnings:

Sass 4.0 deprecated function call

DEPRECATION WARNING: Passing a string to call() is deprecated and will be illegal in Sass 4.0. Use call(get-function(‚Äúmixin-exists‚Äù)) instead.

Ok, that should be easily fixed, just update the theme:

RUNTIME DEPENDENCIES (7):

jekyll ~> 3.6

Oh right, you‚Äôre running jekyll 3.5, time to upgrade! You better use ridk, and where‚Äôs msys2:

MSYS2 could not be found.

Please download and install MSYS2 from https://msys2.github.io/

Fine, I‚Äôll just install msys2:

:: msys2-runtime and catgets are in conflict. Remove catgets? [y/N]

Ah of course, the old catgets, who invited you to the party anyway.

Dependency Error: Yikes! It looks like you don‚Äôt have jekyll-remote-theme or one of its dependencies installed. In order to use Jekyll as currently configured , you‚Äôll need to install this gem. The full error message from Ruby is: ‚ÄòCould n ot open library ‚Äòlibcurl‚Äô: (illegal characters) . Could not open libr ary ‚Äòlibcurl.dll‚Äô: (illegal characters) . Could not open library ‚Äòlib curl.so.4‚Äô: (illegal characters) . Could not open library ‚Äòlibcurl.so .4.dll‚Äô: (illegal characters) ‚Äò If you run into trouble, you can find helpful resources at https://jekyllrb.com/help/!

Oh now we‚Äôre onto a whole new world of pain. So now I‚Äôm fiddling around with pacman, on msys2, updating gcc toolchains‚Ä¶ Right, let‚Äôs get back to the job at hand and install libcurl:

We‚Äôre deep in the rabbit hole now, I‚Äôve forgotten why we started this journey in the first place ü§î. Some downloading and extracting of various libcurl builds later, oh and renaming libcurl-x64.dll to libcurl.dll. Finally curb has done something. Let‚Äôs try again:

I see, of course you have to have the latest ca-cert-bundle.crt, oh and don‚Äôt forget to set the environment variables:

Try again:

SSL certificate problem: unable to get local issuer certificate

Oh right, still doesn‚Äôt work. What exactly are those environment variables doing anyway:

http://www.rubydoc.info/gems/ethon/0.5.0/Ethon/Easy

The CURLOPT_CAPATH function apparently does not work in Windows due to some limitation in openssl.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37551409/configure-curl-to-use-default-system-cert-store

OpenSSL does not support using the ‚ÄúCA certificate store‚Äù that Windows has on its own. If you want your curl build to use that cert store, you need to rebuild curl to use the schannel backend instead

This could be the end of the adventure, we could either download the OpenSSL source and rebuild on windows with WinSSL or find someone who has already built libcurl with WinSSL. Wait a minute, what‚Äôs this:

https://skanthak.homepage.t-online.de/curl.html

X:> i386\curl.exe -V

curl 7.58.0 (i386-pc-win32) libcurl/7.58.0 WinSSL zlib/1.2.11

Finally, 2 days later and I have a functioning jekyll setup on windows 10 with libcurl and jekyll-remote-theme. That was really fun ü§Æ.

entry.title: Jekyll up and running
entry.content:
Jekyll is a tool to create static web pages generated from markdown files. This means you don‚Äôt have to worry about paying for wordpress hosting, or worse setting up a LAMP server, with MySQL/PHP just to host a blog. It‚Äôs got some really useful features, such as syntax highlighting for all the languages that github supports:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to use Jekyll.
